That's 17.5% less Effective HP. Remember, 1 point of Armor or MR is 1% extra HP against that damage type.

That is incorrect there is the law of diminishing returns. resistances is calculated as 1-100/(100+ resistances) * 100% at 200 armor you have 66% dmg reduction. but at 100 you have 50% dmg reduction

It is correct.

If you have 70% DR (233 Armor) against a 0 penetration 100 AD auto attack you will take 30 damage. If you have 1000 HP it will take 34 auto attacks to kill you (30 x 34 = 1020). If you look at this in Effective HP, 233 Armor and 1000 HP is 3330 eHP (1000 x 233%). We now compare the full 100 AD to eHP because it isn't mitigated anymore (100 x 34 = 3400). Same number of autos.

Another example will be 75% DR, or 300 Armor, vs the same 100 AD 0 pen auto attack. 

100 AD would do 25 damage to the target, and with the same health pool of 1000, it would take 40 autos to kill them. (25 x 40 = 1000)
In effective HP the target would have 4000 eHP, so the 100 AD auto would take 40 autos to kill the target (100 x 40 = 4000). Still the same number of autos between normal HP and eHP, right? If we add just _10 points of armor_ to make it 310 Armor, it will take 1 more auto to kill the target because their eHP shot up by 10% to 4100 making the needed autos to kill 41. So even though that 10 armor only increased their DR by ~0.6%, it gave them 10% more eHP.

If you wanna do the more complicated math instead of nice neat numbers, feel free, and I hope this made sense. Pretty tired while writing this.

Penetration in general needs nefs, flat. It doesnt need to exist when we have crit. 

the point of penetration is to augment relatively low damage builds. Crit combined with penetration COMPLETELY breaks penetration because its effectiveness is multiplied with penetration...

Pen and crit are opposite...
You either build AS/Crit build or CDR/ARP. If you do both it sucks hard.
Problem lies in utility of crit items.
Ghostblade, maw, Cleaver, Death's Dance in particular offer tons of utility, while IE, BT, Reaver etc. provide nothing but flat damage...

Also, power spikes are in favor of ARP builds, their power spikes early, allowing snowballing. They don't lose power in mid game, but when lategame comes they are far behind crit builds.

Crit builds tend to shine only after 2-3 big items
